Are there Hallowe'en costumes you don't allow?

We've always steered clear of the medaeival witch-stereotype, not because I believe witches are evil ...

but because the stereotype is offensive to Wiccans, and because of all the harm that that *stereotype* did to innocent people over the centuries that the church promoted it.

The use of the word "witch" in the bible refers directly to that stereotype, not to real witches. King James I -- sponsor of the King James Version translation -- was one of the big promotors of that stereotype and the author of the book "Maleus Maleficarum" that gives us the description of witches as warty, bent-over old hags. And as a result, thousands of poor elderly peasant-women, whose worst offense was to be on the margins of society in a village where an animal died or a child fell ill, were hideously tortured or killed.

The actual words -- in Hebrew kashaph, more often translated as "sorcerer", and qecem, more often translated as "divination"; and in Greek "pharmakeia", more often translated as "sorcery" and better translated as "drug abuse" -- certainly did not, in their original tongue, mean "Priestesses of the Northern-European Nature religion", which is what the root-word of "witch" (wicca) actually refers to.

So, I tend to turn requests for witch-costumes into lectures on social justice: in particular the need to defend powerless old women being steam-rollered by urban legends, the need for religious tolerance, and our need as a church to repent if the harm we have done in the past in the name of evangelism. Usually my children will rapidly accept some less-offensive costume, if only to shut me up <g>.
